name: heat pump production, 30kW | heat pump, 30kW | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/5718/documentation

This dataset represents a 30 kW heat pump unit. Data is extrapolated from a brine-water heat pump for a one family house in Switzerland with a heat capacity of 10 kW. Life time of the heat pump is assumed to be 20 years. ;This dataset represents a 30 kW heat pump unit for European conditions. Data is extrapolated from a brine-water heat pump for a one family house in Switzerland with a heat capacity of 10 kW. Life time of the heat pump is assumed to be 20 years. 

From reception of brine water heat pumps at the factory gate.

This activity ends with a 30 kW heat pump unit with a lifetime of 20 years. The dataset includes emissions caused by refrigerating agent leakages during production process and the disposal of plastic. R134a as refrigerating agent is included. This dataset does not inlcude emissions caused during operation.
category: C:Manufacturing/28:Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c./281:Manufacture of general-purpose machinery/2815:Manufacture of ovens, furnaces and furnace burners

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is based on a 10 kW heat pump unit operated in Switzerland and extrapolated to European conditions.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Brine-water heat pumps use geothermal energy by extracting the heat stored in the ground with a borehole heat exchanger. Borehole heat exchangers basically consist of coaxial or U-shaped polyethylene tubes and are installed vertically in the soil, usually at a depth of 50 up to 250 meters. Thereby the soil serves as heat source. The heat is withdrawn from the soil through a closed-loop system situated in the tube and is fed to the heat pump. As heat-conveying fluid, i.e. brine, in the majority of cases water is used compounded with 25 % to 35% of antifreezing agent. The heat pump then transforms the heat through a second circuit to an appropriate temperature level for low-temperature heating systems. Brine-water heat pumps are more expensive but have a higher annual coefficient of performance compared to air-water heat pumps, i.e. high quality energy is used in a more efficient way. According to Lovvorn and Hess life time of the heat pump is 20 years.;;References:;Brunner M. und Gorhan L.: GEOTHERMIE - DIE UMWELTSCHONENDE ENERGIE. http://www.geothermal-energy.ch/downloads/umweltsch-dt.PDF.;Lovvorn, N.C. (2001). Reliability and Lifetime of Residential Heat Pumps. Paper. Proceedings of Joint HPC and IPUHPC Workshop “Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings,” 10-11 October 2001. Arnhem, The Netherlands. CD-ROM: “Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings,” Workshop Report HPC-WR-23. IEA Heat Pump Centre. Sittard, The Netherlands.;Lovvorn, N.C. (2001). Reliability and Lifetime of Residential Heat Pumps. Power Point Presentation. CD-ROM: “Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings,” Workshop Report HPC-WR-23. IEA Heat Pump Centre. Sittard, The Netherlands.;Persönliche Mitteilung Herr Hess, Firma: Polydynamics Ltd., Zürich, Juli 1993.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: For this dataset a brine-water heat pump for Swiss conditions with a heat capacity of 10 kW was extrapolated to a heat pump with a heat capacity of 30 kW for European conditions.
